review_title: Hallmark Healthcare works for a basic job, not a career.
pros: Hallmark provides pay and benefits that are average for the area.  Daily patient care is as expected at 80% billable productivity which is common in our area but often difficult to meet honestly. The caseload fluctuates and you are not allowed to stay late without prior authorization but you are expected to leave early without pay when the caseload is low.  They are agreeable to bringing in outside per diem help when busy which helps with the stressful feelings when you are told to compete your temporarily high patient care load within the daily time limits by cutting back on individual time spent per patient. They are conveniently located to my home. Payroll is usually accurate and on time.
cons: The biggest problem is unfairness in promotions, lack of loyalty to their existing employees, and apparent discrepancies in salaries, benefits and bonuses. I particularly dislike how fair or good per diem employees who have worked for months or years are not given work in favor of new per diem people who are friends of the manager.  And how outside employees are recruited with huge bonuses yet existing employees are given very small (2%) raises and not allowed to increase hours (at regular pay, not overtime), yet are expected to go home early when the caseload is low without pay.  Also, daily scheduled breaks and lunches are applied inconsistently between managers.  And 6 hour employees are required to take lunch break when neither the state nor the caseload require it.  Different buildings receive different benefits of free lunches, free work shirts or lab coats and my building does not or rarely, yet I think it is a benefit.  Outside educational classes may be paid to some employees but there is no known policy and nothing has been paid to me in three and a half years.
